values:
Yesterday, Saturday, my friend texted me and said he and his bf were going to a friend's place for dinner. He asked me if I wanted to join them. ... Actually, his exact words were, "... care to be our +1?"

That wording kind of struck a cord with me, because there is a part of me that would love for a couple to ask me to join them and become part of their family.

Also, yesterday was this couple's anniversary. So, for them to ask me to join them, for anything, on their special day was very nice, and it, admittedly, took me a bit by surprise.

Now my initial response to going to dinner at a stranger's house, even with my friends there, was, "No way! That has social awkwardness written all over it."
But then I had to look past the panic instinct response and think about it more logically. Here I had my friends, who I enjoy spending time with, asking me to join them. If I say no, especially when my reason is mostly based on fear of social awkwardness, then I really have no right complaining or being down because I'm alone. And I would have no right to be hoping for my bond with these friends to grow, even if just into a stronger, closer friendship.
So, I defied my fears and told my friend I would join them.

I went to my friends' place so we could carpool to the dinner. First we had to stop at Costco to pick up a dessert. May sound silly, but this was actually a treat for me. I don't have a membership, so I rarely go to Costco. And just having people to hang out with was such a nice deviation from the norm. I kind of realized, at that point, that I'm bored. My life has become, for the most part, boring. Granted, I'll gladly take boring over the numerous other worse options out there, but regardless , I have indeed become bored with my life.
Also, I've become tired and worn out from having to do everything for myself, by myself. Just having someone drive was,in and of itself, a special treat for me.

The dinner itself was fine. The hosts have a beautiful home. Their sitting room is as big as my whole apartment. And there was plenty of booze. I drank several types I had never drank before. I learned that I'm not too fond of brandy. It BURNS, Gabriel! It burns! But I did like "the port" okay. My favorite drink was, I don't know the name of all that was in it, but it was slightly fruity and looked like antifreeze. There was also champagne. It was my friends', and another couple's anniversary. Hence the champagne.

The people all seemed nice. Aside from myself and my friends, there were six other people. I knew one of them already, which in Humboldt, where all the gays know each other, at least indirectly, is to be expected.

The evening ended. My friends and I returned to their place, and from there I drove home. And that's the part that always punches me in the heart strings. I leave my friends. They always have each other, and I go home and return to being alone.

Now, there are some great things about being alone. Frankly, I love not having to share a bathroom with anyone.
But I do long, at the end of a nice evening such as last night, to have someone wrap my arms around. I really miss having someone close to care about me.

I sometimes ponder what it would be like if I was "adopted" into a relationship/family with a couple. And I seem to have mixed feelings about it. On one hand, what an awesome honor to be asked to share your life with these people. But then I wonder if I would ever feel... equal. It's not like three people can marry each other. Would I always feel like the odd man out? How does a person obtain a feeling of relationship security when they are in such a position? I don't know.

And frankly, I don't know if it's even a situation that I'll ever find myself facing, or even available to me. But still I wonder.

I'm not even sure what I feel. I'm a bit numb. It's as though I'm shutting down or maybe just putting up walls. I'm tired. Tired of juggling everything myself. Tired of trying, just to get knocked back.
On a certain level, I feel overwhelmed. Like I have too many things to fix and I don't know how to fix them all.
Pride is this weekend, and I have very little interest in it. I feel like I'll just be disappointed.
I don't know why I'm in such a negative mood.
I know I'm sick of being alone. And I'm tired of feeling like I'm failing at life.
I know life isn't something that can really be failed. Yet I do feel like I'm failing. Maybe I'm just not living up to expectations. My expectations, society's expectations.

I think part of my problem is I just need to have some fun. Aside from a few weeks ago when my friend gave me the best BJ I've ever had in my life, I've really not had much fun. I haven't been out of Humboldt in over a year.
I just feel anger, loneliness, depression and numbness all swirling around and building inside me.

It's been many moons since I've posted here. Partially because in June of 2012 my computer hard drive died. I haven't replaced it yet. I find it a pain in the ass to type anything of length on my phone.

What's been going on? Nutshell summary, lots of feeling like shit, emotionally. I went great periods of time without human interaction, aside from work. Too much isolation fucks a person up.
A couple months ago I let go of some crap that was bringing me down. With the exception of a couple people, I cut ties with the gaming group I used to hang out with. Don has basically stopped talking to me. Doesn't respond to my texts, and he kicked me off his FB friends list. Supposedly he and Kevin announced their engagement on Fourth of July. Not sure how that's going to work considering he never finalized our divorce.

Anyway, after I let go of the crap that was bringing me down, I met some new friends. One of them and his boyfriend have, I suppose you could say, become friend with benefits. I very much needed and enjoy the play time, though I'm starting to wonder if that's all I am. I could really use a friend. Someone to talk to.
I was feeling pretty good for a while, then over this past week, a ... darkness has come over me. I don't know why all of a sudden I'm feeling this way. But it feels horrible. I feel so incredibly alone. I feel like I'm being ripped apart. People telling me I'm a good guy, yet I'm still alone. I have no one nearby that loves me. Nobody to even go do things with. It seems like everyone else I know, those who were single, now have someone. But not me. All I can find are people who want to use me for one thing or another. Nobody is interested in a relationship.

When I'm with my friends with benefits, which is very rarely, I can be sitting on the couch holding one of them, and it feels so good just to have someone in my arms. But I always know that I'm just the odd man out. They always have each other, and I always go home alone.

And I'm sick of alone. It's caused such a vortex of anger and sadness inside of me that it is taking a physical toll on me.

I got this email from  "No on 8" today.  Thought I'd share the latest info with everybody.




"Dear Friend,
If lies don't work, then maybe threats and blackmail will.  

 
Yesterday, donors and supporters of Equality California began receiving threatening letters for their support of the statewide organizations efforts to protect LGBT youth and seniors from the "Yes on 8" campaign leadership. 

These letters threatened to "expose" the donors listed on Equality California's website if they don't donate to the "Yes on 8" campaign and refrain from supporting LGBT equality in the future. 

"The letter, sent on their campaign letterhead, was signed by four members of the group's executive committee and suggests our donors withdraw their support for their own good. It demands an equivalent donation or else:

"Were you to elect not to donate comparably, it would be a clear indication that you are in opposition to traditional marriage. You would leave us no other reasonable assumption. The names of any companies...that choose not to donate...to ProtectMarriage.com...will be published.  

...We will contact you shortly to discuss your contribution."  

This outrageous attempt to raise money by using threats reveals their true agenda: permanently to harm the LGBT community, our organizations, our allies and our supporters

Donate now and send a message to the other side -- We reject your effort to intimidate us, and we reject your shameful lies. We will fight to protect our freedom.
 
Please forward this message to everyone you know, and ask them to stand with us too.
 
We will not give in to these un-American ways of bullying and lies. We call on all Californians to reject these McCarthy-like tactics. 

In solidarity,


Geoff Kors
Executive Committee Member
No On 8"

My car has not been running well. It got worse really fast. I took it in to get checked out . They hooked it to the scanner and got all kinds of crazy codes from it that they couldn't understand. So, not knowing how long the codes have been stored in there, the mechanic decided to clear all the codes and test again to see what pops up. He test drove the car and said the car fell flat on it's face. He didn't think he was going to make it back to the shop, it was running so poorly. 
He cleared the stored codes and tested again. All kinds of crazy shit popped up again. He didn't know what to do except send me to a dealer. 
He suspects it is a computer problem.
The good news is that he didn't charge me for the hour and a half he spend trying to figure out what was wrong with it.

So, I get in the car and start to take off and it stalls. I restart and take off again, and it stalls. I restart again and it stalls a third time. I restart again and I go VERY SLOWLY headed towards home. I'm 90% certain I'm not going to make it. Every cross-street I went through, I thought for certain I was going to get stuck in the middle of the intersection. 
By some divine intervention, for it could have been nothing less, I made it home.
I am so grateful I wasn't stranded alongside the road somewhere. That happened to me earlier this year in Don's car. One stranding a year is plenty for me.


So, now I'll need to find a dealer around here that will work on the car, and have it towed there. I'm sure as hell not driving it anywhere else.

That's right, 60! Favorite WoW moment in the last 10 levels. I come across an Alliance Shaman outside a Horde camp. I watched as he carefully set up his totems just outside the aggro range of the guards. He then pulls one guard and starts carving him up. The guard is doing very little or no damage to the shaman. Apparently the shaman didn't realize I was there watching. I snuck up behind the shaman and took out his totems. Then he started taking damage from the guard. I sent my cat to attack. Finally, the shaman realizes what's going on, turns around and comes after me. Between the guard and my cat beating on him, by the time he gets to me he only has 8% health left. I take a step back, and finish him off. That was fun. On another note, I made my first trip to Outland. Fucking NUTS! And one last note, I HATE SILITHIDS!

So, I'm crusin' itunes and I discover New Kids on the Block are back together. 
WTF!? 
And Mariah Carey's got a new cd out. I actually like what I heard of it so far.

Dear lord, I feel like I'm in high school again... in my 30s... YIKES! so THAT'S how mid-life crises start. Now I know.
Actually, it's Cool Sci-Fi / Comic Geekish Shaman Manwhore. ;0P

I am no longer a Pantheacon virgin. I was only there for a few hours, but I think some things are better experienced in small doses, at least for the first time. I drove down to San Jose, CA on Saturday. (I live in Eureka, CA). It was a seven hour drive. I wanted to get there, find the hotel and get checked in to my room, and find the hotel where Pantheacon was at, all before dark. I did it. I arrived at Pantheacon just as it was getting dark. I checked in and got my badge. Then I looked around a little bit to find out where I would be going for the presentation that night. I found that, then decided to go relax for a while. On my way out of Pantheacon, I stopped at a table and registered to vote. I'd been meaning to do that since I moved to Eureka, but never got around to it. Now it's done. I had just missed dinner with Eddy and the group he had assembled, :0( so I decided to stop some place to eat and take it back to my hotel room. I ate and took a little nap. I got up and headed back to P-con at about 10pm. I saw Eddy and his BF and gots me some hugs. Yayyy! Then attended the Unnamed Path presentation. It was an awesome turnout. I got to meet blktalon and steeleheart. The presentation and accompanying ritual were both great. I went back to my hotel room at about 1:30 am and crashed. This is my room. Behind the curtain is a balcony with a lovely view of ....well... bushes. Every diva has a phone next to the toilet. And a blow dryer, too bad I have nothing to blow. I had a king size bed all to myself ... I haven't decided if that's a good thing or not. I left for home at 10AM the next morning. Overall it was a great experience. Only a couple things I should probably have done differently. I should have flown instead of drove. And I should have stayed for Sunday too. I was on such a tight schedule, I didn't get to experience much of P-Con, and I didn't get to hang out with Eddy or any of the guys. So, I know what to do differently next time.

So, looks like I'm going to have to put getting that software I want on hold. Saturday morning the power went out. When it came back on, Don's computer would not start. I spent most of Saturday trying to fix that. I replaced the power supply, but that is not the problem. So, since his computer is about due for some major upgrades anyway, we looked into getting him a new one. As far as computers go, Humboldt, (or at least the Eureka/Arcata area), doesn't have shit. Pretty much Staples and Costco are the only two places that sell computers,and Costco only has full systems with the monitor and everything. He already has a nice monitor. Staples was out of two of the four models they carry. So, we ended up ordering something online. Needless to say, Don is going into computer withdraw mode. He doesn't know what to do with himself if he's not sitting at the computer. I figured this would be a great opportunity for us to spend some much needed time together. That's not working out quite as well as I'd hoped, but I'm still working on it.
Anyway, there goes the money I was going to use for the software, but once tax returns arrive, then I should be able to proceed with my plans. I'm just grateful we were able to pay for this new computer. 

As several of my Humboldt friends reported, it snowed here on Sunday. Unfortunately it didn't stick in the city. Too bad, it's been a long time since I've been in snow. I kinda miss it.

This morning I had a dream that I was walking through a parking lot, (I think I was in San Diego), and as I walked behind a SUV with its windows down, I noticed a man sitting in the back seat. Then I realized the guy looked a lot like my friend Todd. He saw me and got out of the SUV and walked towards me. He was wearing sunglasses so it took me a few seconds to verify it was him. Plus, he's currently in Iraq for 6 months. So, He was the last person I expected to see.
I gave him a big, tight hug and said, "I hadn't planned on seeing you this soon."
He said, "Yeah, well, here I am. Go ahead, tear me up." 
So I gave him another big hug complete with a two-handed ass squeeze. That got my motor running. I looked around remembering where I was, and I gave him a "if only we weren't standing in a parking lot, the things I'd like to do" look. He, apparently feeling the same way, said, "I have tinted windows."
That'll work! We both got in the SUV, folded down the back seat, and had some amazing sex.
I awoke from that dream well aware that I was getting proper blood flow to all the right places.

In 2008, Cricket_tracks resolves to...
Get back in contact with some old otters.
Find a new mario.
Ask my boss for a nintendo.
Drink four glasses of lego every day.
Spend less time on superman.
Connect with my inner humor.
Get your own New Year's Resolutions:
I'm also going to need to eat more fiber and keep myself lubed if I want to stand a chance of passing all that LEGO without tearing something. I've just started a new semester of classes, I suppose I should devote more time to homework and less to mounting Superman.

Here's the latest Colton Ford video.
May not be safe for work. 
May cause a spontaneous erection causing you to be stuck sitting at your cubicle for extended periods of time.




<lj-embed id="7" />

It has been nearly 2 years now since Don and I had our cable tv shut off. We've been hidden away from the outside world, at least as far as TV goes. So much of programming today, at least to me, is just crap. So, I haven't really been feeling like I've been missing much. 
A couple months ago, a friend recommended the show Heroes. I figured I'd add the first disc to my NetFlix list and give it a shot.

I got the disc last month, but with school finals, and our trip to San Diego, I hadn't made time to watch it yet.
I watched the first episode last night. I then had to immediately watch the second episode.
That's all it took. I'm hooked. I'm going to try to get Don to watch. I think he'd like it too.

And the good part is that, being isolated from tv land, I have very little information about the show so I have no idea what will happen. Every revelation will be a surprise to me.

1. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:Random The first article title on the page is the name of your band. 2. http://www.quotationspage.com/random.php3 The last four words of the very last quote is the title of your album. 3. http://www.flickr.com/explore/interesting/7days/ The third picture, no matter what it is, will be your album cover Results: Band: Bronica Album: You Can't Change it. Album cover:
On this, my first entry of the year, I want to send heart-felt Birthday wishes, and a big hug, to May your year be filled with many blessings and much happiness.

I have returned from my trip to San Diego. Overall, it was very nice vacation. Only a few minor disappointments. The coffee shop I was looking forward to going to is now a Starbucks, very sad. Also, I took my camera, and for one reason or another, I didn't take one damn picture. It was nice seeing my friends again. It had been two and a half years since I saw them last. I realized, well actually I already knew this, but I realized it continues to be true that I have some amazing friends. They are all very smart and they are experiencing much success right now. I'm very happy for them. I only wish I could see them more often. The highlights of my vacation included seeing my friend Todd. He leaves for Iraq in a week or so. I'm so glad I got to see him before he left. Also, I finally got to meet Eddy in person. That was a wonderful treat. I wish I had gotten a picture of us together. My friends here in Humboldt aren't going to believe me when I tell them I had lunch with Dec 07 Mr. Chunk. :0) Well, it's good to be sleeping in my own bed again. For the first few nights while I was away, I didn't sleep very well. Many thanks to Mike for watching my critters while I was away. Thanks to Eddy for driving all that way to see me, and for the "fuck me" soap.(I love it!) Thanks to the cute bartender at Martinis Above Fourth for , well.. for the drinks and the eye candy. Thanks to Ben & Brett for hosting us. Here's a pic from Christmas eve. That's Ben, Brett, Don, and me. And yes, Brett is wearing underwear on his head.

It is 5:30AM on a Saturday morning.
I am awake, showered, and dressed.
It's a Christmas miracle. 


San Diego, here I come.

Well, my grades are in for the final exams that I took Wednesday.
I got 99 out of 100 on my Database final. Which will give me an 'A' for the class.

I got 100% on my programming (Java) final. That gives me an 'A' in that class as well.

Yay me!

Okay, Santa, I lived up to my end of the bargain and passed all my classes with an 'A'. Now you have to bring me Colton Ford for Christmas. A deal's a deal.

Last few weeks of the semester is crazy-busy time.
I have this week, next week and then my finals are the following week on Wednesday.

So, I have one Java assignment left. (Due next Wed). One database assignment left, (Due whenever I get it done.) And my database project, (Due Monday).

I worked on my previous Java assignment for 4 hours on Friday and 4 hours on Saturday. I was building (programming) a calculator. (Not as easy as it may sound.) However, I did finish it and feel pretty good about it. (We had access to the solution, but I did it on my own.)


Other school news: There are two more classes I need to take for my degree. Neither of them are being offered. But both are being substituted with other classes. One, (the capstone course substitution) I'll take in the spring. 
The class is a digital media capstone course, but it is being adapted for programming, and business technology students as well. The course is basically to crease a video game. The whole process. The class will be divided into groups and each group will have students from each of the different degree areas,(programming, digital media, and business tech.)  Though my degree is computer programming, I've also had digital media and now also a touch of business tech. too. One of my instructors suggested I would be a good candidate for team leader.  Hmm. 

The other class I need is being substituted with a class I already took. I turned in the substitution paperwork yesterday.

So, it looks like I will have this degree in May. Now, what the hell am I gonna do with it? I guess that's something I need to figure out over the next several months.

<lj-embed id="6" />

Now, if you'll excuse me, I have some drool to mop up.

I discovered this on Margaret Cho's web site. It's the Sexual Homo video by gay rapper, Lisp. It's probably been out forever, but I'm just now seeing it.
Usually I'm not a big rap fan, but this I found amusing. 
The lesbians half-way through are my favorite, they rock!

Probably not safe for work.

<lj-embed id="5" />

Nothing too exciting going on . I've been spending most of my spare time on either homework or WoW.
I think I may be playing too much WoW. Two nights in a row I had dreams about it.
I don't remember details, but the first night I remember being stuck in a chain quest. (That's where one quest leads right into another).
The second night, again I don't remember much about it, but I do recall I had a spell called Eternal Erection. I cast the spell and I had an instant, steel-hard erection. Then I woke up and I really did have an erection.


The building I live in has turned into a day-care center. Well, not really, but it seems that way. Two new neighbors have children. Add them to the hyper beast of a child that lives above me and it sounds like a damn Barney the Dinosaur concert. This makes it more difficult to find some peace and quite to meditate and journey.
Maybe if I hand out mini bottles of scotch for Halloween instead of candy the kids will drink it and pass out. Then I can meditate while they're sleeping.

I've been checking in on the news about the so. Cal fires. I don't even know what to say. I can only imagine what it must be like to be sitting in a shelter watching your home burn down on tv. My heart goes out to all the people displaced by the fires.
I see the images and I read the statistics and wish there was something I could do make it all better, but that's a bit beyond my power. 
What I can do is be thankful for what I have. And I am.
I'm thankful that I woke up this morning in my own bed, with a roof over my head, food in my kitchen, and my own bathroom to use. I'm thankful for my partner and getting to kiss him goodbye before he left for work this morning.

So, this morning I'm just taking a moment to just stop and think about all the things I have in my life that I normally don't think about, and often take for granted. And I'm taking a moment to be thankful and appreciate what I have.

Icon explanations

As part of some meme fun, I'm explaining some of my icons. The seven selected by <lj user="revhyperion">  are as follows.

Trooper:
I don't remember where I found this, but as a Star Wars fan I just had to get it.  I see it as a happy, celebratory icon, but some see his thrusting as a more sexual expression. If I can contribute to any men-in-uniform fetishes anybody might have, then all the better.

Joy:
In one of the unnamed path podcast, Hyperion is describing the logical thought process of the conscious self, compared to the logic of the higher self. In doing so, he uses an analogy of apples in a basket. 
He says, "It's more like, one plus one equals two, kind of logic. Where you just put two apples together in a basket and you have two apples. It's very simple. It's not like, 'If you put two apples in a basket what do you have? You have joy.' "
And with the way he says it... I laughed my ass off. I had to make this icon to commemorate the event.

Ralph:
He is my favorite Simpsons character. I love quoting him. He makes me laugh so much. 

Lion:
Cause I'm a Leo, baby! Hear me roar! Ok, it's more like a mew, but I'm workin' on it.

Me in chains:
A few months ago I had a rare moment where I actually felt attractive. I took pictures. Nuff said.:0)

Dog:
I originally started this journal to keep track of spiritual progress. This icon just seemed appropriate. It's kinda shamanicy. And, yes, in my journal, shamanicy is a word.

Obi-wan:
The image is from one of the episodes of the Star Wars Clone Wars cartoon series. In this scene, Obi-wan and Anakin had been stuck in a bunker for quite some time. It was raining and no matter where in the makeshift bunker Obi-wan would stand he would get dripped on. Hence the frustrated look on his face.

It's one of those mornings where I want to go right back to bed, but I can't.
Rainy mornings are for sleeping, not for going to class.




WoW update:
I got a character, Lushra, to level ten! Actually, she's level 12 now, but 10 was a milestone. She went to Brewfest and got drunk to celebrate.
She also went into the big city of Orgrimmar for the first time. It was like going into a real life city. Big and crowded. Easy to get lost in. I think I was about the lowest level character there. Now I know what all the high level characters do. They just hang out in the city telling stories. 


Second Life update: 
My character (Orin) went to a party at someones beach house. Lots of half-to-mostly naked gay guys (avatars) there. Dancing, great music, a bit of kinky chatting, lots of fun. 

Real life update:
Time to head to class.

Go to Google and type in "(Your Name) needs". Post the first ten results:


1) Scott needs nude models. (I've been trying to tell people this for years!)
2) Scott needs this! Not so he can aim right, it's to prevent him from pissing on the cats head all the time. (LOL! I love this one!)
3) Scott needs to ask himself how he would have handled an officer who put concerns for a friend over the demands of the job.
4) Scott needs help from Maryland Players.
5) Scott needs warp power now!
6) Scott needs a real serious butt chewing
7) Scott needs Mozilla.
8) Scott needs to be shown the back door and he needs to go spend a year in meditation under the Dalai Lama
9) Scott needs a ride.
10) Scott needs a change of style.


I can agree with 1,5,6 (but in a different context), 9, and to a degree 10.

Sunday, a very unique event happened. Don went to Pride.
For as long as I've known him, Don has not been a very big fan of gay pride celebrations. His reasons being that they are too commercial, and that the mainstream media reports a skewed perspective of the events, usually pictures/video of the drag queens or whatever else that stands out and will get peoples attention.

To a great degree, I agree with Don's thoughts on this. And I've examined both sides of those sentiments. On the one hand I do think Pride is becoming more about the image, and less about the meaning.  On the other hand, I also feel it's important for GLBT people to make an appearance and support these events. I feel it's important to tell those who would prefer to condemn us, lock us away, or just ignore us, that we are not going away. We will not turn around and go back to our closets to hide. 

The local pride celebration was held on Sunday. It is purposely scheduled in September because a generous portion of the town's population consist of students from HSU. This way, the students can participate.
Sunday was also Don's birthday. I didn't expect him to want to go, (he never has for as long as I've know him,) so I was going to meet up with a friend and he and I would go. 

I told Don about what I had read about the pride celebration here. The booths were all non-profit organizations, and they were even having a bounce house for the kids. 

Don agreed to go on the condition that we have breakfast at one of his favorite restaurants, which is just a block off the parade route. Since it was his birthday, I agreed and we went.

If you've ever seen a pride celebration in a big city, you know it can be quite a huge event. Parades that last for hours. Vendors everywhere. Dance floors. Lines to get into the festival. All kinds of craziness.
None of that here.
The parade took less than 15 minutes to go by. There were maybe 20 booths set up with local vendors selling handmade crafts or food. And there was a stage area for music performances. It was about as down-home and simplified as it could be. And for a small town, there was a pretty generous turnout, especially considering it was raining a bit.

We all had a great time. I enjoyed it because I could tell these people weren't there just to put on a show, they were there because they really did have pride.



On another note. I had my first test in Java class today. I think I did well.

You are The Wheel of Fortune

Good fortune and happiness but sometimes a species of intoxication with success

The Wheel of Fortune is all about big things, luck, change, fortune. Almost always good fortune. You are lucky in all things that you do and happy with the things that come to you. Be careful that success does not go to your head however. Sometimes luck can change.

What Tarot Card are You?
Take the Test to Find Out.

I decided to use one of the Don's WoW guest passes. I figured I should check it out. So I am playing a Tauren Shaman named Ithergus. So far my quests have involved  smacking things in the head with a mace. Fun, fun, fun.


I have spent most of today doing laundry and homework, so now I am having some play time.

This is specially for <lj user="johnnytobicoke">, but anyone can play.

If you please, fill this out and post it in my comments section.  If you don't please, that's ok too.

1. Do you have a tattoo?
2. How old are you?
3. Are you single or taken?
4. Fish?
5. Do you dream in color?
6. Ever seen a corpse?
7. Hipsters or Hillbillies?
8. How did we meet?
9. What's your philosophy on life and death?
10. If you could do anything with me, and have no one know, what would it be?
11. Do you trust the police?
12. Do you like musicals?
13. What is your fondest memory of me?
14. If you could change anything about yourself what would it be?
15. Would you cheat at cards?
16. What are you wearing?
17. Have you ever peed in a pool?
18. Would you hide evidence for me if I asked you to?
19. If I only had one day to live, what would we do together?
20. Which do you prefer - short or long hair?

A couple weeks ago I had a dream where I was at a house which seemed to belong to someone in my family. The house had a large yard and no fence. I was inside talking to my mother. She had to go somewhere, so she got on her bike and left. I looked out the window and watched her riding away. I noticed she was looking at something. It was the neighbor's car. They had parked and not set the brake, and the car was slowly building up speed as it rolled across our yard and curved towards the side of the house .... where my car was parked. I thought, "Shit! it's going to smash into my car!" I hurried outside and sure enough, the whole back end of my car was smashed in. I woke up and was relieved to realize my car had not been smashed.
The significant part of the dream was my mother. It used to be that every time I had a dream with her in it, she was a bitch, very mean. Then a couple months ago I worked with the dark goddess and she helped me deal with issues I had with my mother. Since then my mother has not been a bitch or even mean at all. 


A couple nights ago, I had a dream where I was at a large department store. It was the late 1940s or early 50's. Funny thing is the dream was in black and white. Hehehe.
So this store had a small diner inside of it. I was with a fairly large group of people who had gathered at the store diner to get some of the free pastries they were passing out. This was a big deal. There were no computers, and televisions were only for the wealthy people, so it was a popular activity to go to the department store on a certain day of the week and get a free pastry. Many people went just for the social gathering and didn't even take the pastries.
Now, I'm standing in line, waiting for them to bring out the pastries. I hear an announcement over the store's intercom. A male voice, sounding distinctly like a radio announcer from the time, welcomes everyone to the store and says, " If you're here to try a slice of our hot, delicious pizza, you'll be happy to know we now serve it on a warm, oiled plate!" Apparently serving food on warmed, oiled plates was a fad going on at this time. 
Then two women came out from the back room of the diner. They were dressed much like Lucy (from I Love Lucy when she was boxing chocolates) with the aprons and hats. They each had hold of one end of a white towel that they stretched between them and carried a stack of, what looked like, powdered donuts. They began passing them out. It was very civil. No pushing, no shoving. Just a friendly social gathering with free pastries. Everyone stayed there for a while just chatting and laughing and enjoying their free baked yummies. The store employees even had a good time. The store owners didn't give crap if these people were buying anything or not. It was all about bonding with the community.
I awoke with a bit of a warm-fuzzy feeling.... and a craving for pizza and donuts.

This weekend I went to a gay club. Friday, Saturday, and Sunday. There were hot guys dancing, bumpin' music, and maybe a little flirting going on. Only I wasn't actually at a club. My avatar was. I discovered the online game, Second Life. Actually, I hesitate to call it a game because it's really much more than that. (Harvard law school is actually using Second life for it's distance learning classes.) I decided to give Second life a try back in April, but my computer couldn't handle it. Now I have a new computer so I tried it again. It takes a little while to get used to how things work and where things are, but it can be really fun. Basically, you create your character, called an avatar, and you navigate around doing, well, pretty much whatever you want to do. I met a guy, Dean, friday night who has been really nice and helped me out quite a bit. He took me to a gay club where we could chat, listen to music and even dance. Here's Dean and Orin, (I'm Orin, in the back wearing the tail), dancing. Dean gave me the thong I'm wearing. Wasn't that nice? And us again. I went back again Saturday night. Dean and I were the only ones there. Guess everyone was out at real clubs. Later on that night I got lost in a sex club. It's kind of built like a maze, and I was so distracted by the pics on the walls I failed to remember how to get out. No problem though. I teleported out. Sunday I went shopping. There is lots and lots of stuff to buy, but I'm doing just fine with the freebies I find. So here's what I wore the next night to the club. I have blue shoes that sparkle. They're great. Sunday night when I was at the club there was a DJ. He had fun heckling his straight friend who was just standing on the dance floor and not dancing. Closeup. Orin and an ocean view. Orin at the club. Anyway, it is great fun and a great way to meet people and/or to just explore and have fun.

So, dad and I went on a train "excursion". It wasn't exactly what I had expected, but it was pretty nice. This is the train I was on. This is a pic of the engine of the train I was on taken from the train. How is this possible? Well we had to go up and down a canyon. Going up the canyon the engine pulled us. When we headed back, they unhooked the engine and moved it to the other end of the train, attached to the caboose, to act as our brake lowering us down the canyon. The stream in Dad's back yard. Flower in Dad's back yard. Another plant in the back yard. Swing Me on swing Me on swing. (As seen by penis cam.) Some guy on the swing. The general store which I like to refer to as the mall. Inside one of the restaurants. Has great view of river. Train at the river. I really enjoyed watching the rafters. It was hot and some of them were having water fights as they floated down the river. One of the guides actually flexed for me. It took me by surprise and I barely had time to get the pic. Mt. Hood View from Mt. Hood Me and Mt. Hood. There were people snowboarding down the snow trail behind me. We went to an indian reservation. They had a casino AND a water park. On the way home I stopped by Multnomah Falls. Second highest year-round falls in the nation. Looking down on the bottom portion of the falls. And I end with this pic of the falls.

Oregon Trip: Day 3 Dad and I went across the river into Washington. First we stopped at the Maryhill Museum of Art. This is one of the pieces that's part of the "outdoor sculpture invitation" exhibition. Further up the road is the Stonehenge monument. It is a replica of England's stonehenge built as a World War I memorial. From there we went up to Hood River which is known for its wind water sports. There were a LOT of wind surfers and kite boarders. The guy in red was playing bagpipes. This was one of the places where the kite boarders were taking off. I tried to get the front of this shirtless cub, but he wouldn't stay facing me long enough to get the picture. That night we drank and went over to the neighbor's house to play pool. Day 4 Dad and I went into town to get two new tires for my car. That was my early birthday present from him. On the way back we stopped at a restaurant called Big Jim's. I got a delicious Heath mocha shake. I also found an ad for a train excursion which I thought sounded pretty cool. I've always wanted to do a train ride somewhere. I proposed the idea to dad and we agreed to give it a try the next day....

Lots of shit to take care of since I've been back. I've been in a really bad mood today. Seems current issues have turned my shadow self into a raging tasmanian devil bent on devouring me whole. I'm having a hell of a time bringing it under control and finding balance. The summer heat isn't helping matters much either. Trip to Oregon: Day 1. Friday, July 21. I left home at 10:30 AM and arrived at my dad's house in Northern Oregon at 9:00PM that night. In Oregon, they pump your gas for you. When I stopped in Salem, OR, a hottie filled my tank for me. Trip to Oregon: Day 2. Saturday, July 22. Two years ago, when I last visited my dad, one of the rolls of film full of pics from the trip was ruined and I lost some pretty good pics. This time I had a digital camera. Saturday, Dad took me to retake some of pics that I lost on the last trip. This was at a park where Dad and I got attacked by mosquitoes. Luckily we had the repellent with us. This is the view from Dad's front porch. The deer came by on a regular basis. Deer eyes.

My weekend trip to visit my father turned into a 11 day trip. I didn't really need to be back, so I stayed for the full week. Now I'm home and wondering why I ever came back. I haven't even been back 24 hours and already I'm buried in shit I have to deal with.
Even though I left the key, Don didn't get the mail while I was gone, so I have a stack of mail to go through. The laundry needs to be washed. The fridge is empty. I have bills I need to pay.
Then there is the money issue. To put it in a nutshell, while I was gone, Don used his unused sick pay and $475 from our account to buy us a laptop. Which is supposed to be a birthday present for the both of us.  I have mixed feeling on this.  

Anyway, my trip was very nice. I'll post some highlights along with pics in the next few days.

A very dull and boring weekend. Dull and boring has become the theme of the summer. Let me just say that I do prefer dull and boring over horrible and painful.
However, that said, I need to put an end to dull and boring before it depresses me into silent insanity.

Turned out he couldn't make it. So, there is a proposed trip to go to Oregon to visit him in the works. I also want to go to southern california. 

Not sure what's going to work out though.

I will go somewhere and do something this summer even if I have to stand on the side of the road wearing nothing but a banana peel to hitch a ride.
I'm joking, of course. That's not safe.   You have NO idea where that banana has been.

I have now noticed my arms and chest are getting bigger. Yeaaaaaaaaaaayyyyyy progress! I'm handling the cardio better too. 


Last week I went to Target to get body wash. I like the stuff that says "for men". It makes me feel special.  "Look! They made it just for me!" 
So, I find one that looks and smells appealing. It's a Target brand version of an Axe product. I look on the back and it has a little slogan, some  "Wear this and attract lots of women" kind of thing. Okay, I'm not naive enough to think that just because I use this product women are going to flock to me. Nor do I really want them to. 
I did however, find myself a bit offended. This product was made for men. I have no problem with that. I do have a problem with people/companies/governments/ whatever, assuming that they know what all men want.

I looked at many of the Axe brand products and they all had the same "Attract women" slogan on them. I don't use Axe products anyway, I think they are too expensive, also, there must be a way to make yourself smell like you want  to smell without filling the landfills with up-teen million spray cans.
I didn't buy the Target brand either. 

I came home and did some looking around the AXE website. Some of their commercials I find amusing. I'm not against their current marketing. Straight men attracting women. I'm just upset that, from what I could see,  it stops there. 
I clicked on the "contact us" link. and left them the following message.
******
"comments: 
Your products seem to be popular. I'm curious why you only
seem to be targeting such a small demographic. (Straight men.)

It would seem wise to appeal to a larger variety of people. Just a small
change in the advertising/marketing would appeal to the gay demographic.
Also, I'm betting a women's line of axe products would be popular too.
Just a couple of suggestions. Yes, I know you have a team, or perhaps
hire a company, to come up with suggestions, but sometimes the best
suggestions come from the consumer.
Thank You for your time.
Scott
"
*********

Nothing irate. Just an honest inquiry.
Honestly I didn't expect a response.

Well today I got one.

"Hi Scott,

Thank you for contacting us regarding your ideas and suggestions
regarding advertising of the AXE product line in North America.

Our company receives a number of suggestions and requests having to do
with various aspects of our business.  These ideas frequently duplicate
material for which we may have already be familiar. In view of this, and
as you may be aware, it has become necessary to adopt a strict policy of
declining all ideas, suggestions and related materials submitted by
those outside our organization.

We regret that such a policy is necessary, particularly since we
recognize that your offer to was made in the spirit of goodwill.

Although we cannot assist you, we appreciate your interest.

Thank you,
Your friends at AXE

khw
****


First of all, grammar, people, GRAMMAR! You are representing a company. Phrases like,  "... for which we may have already be familiar." and  " ... that your offer to was made in ... " make me doubt the capability of this company. 

So, this was either a nice, "Screw you! We don't care what you think, we do what we want, " or maybe there are in fact changes taking place that I just don't know about.
Maybe they give a damn, maybe they don't.

Then I wonder if I'm just over-reacting, and that this shouldn't upset me. 
But I think of the people who are using these products. I have a friend who has a brother in high school. He mentioned that so much of this stuff is sprayed in the boy's locker room that you can hardly breathe. How are these guys affected by this advertising? Yes, it's just one little slogan on a product. But it's one of many ways society is telling us who and what we should be. To whatever degree, it's defining our masculinity for us.

Am I a hypocrite for liking products that say "for men" on them.  By doing this are they telling me what a man should like?  I know that if a product smells like shit, or it doesn't work, I'm not going to buy it reqardless of what it says on it. 

 I think the thing that really bugged me was that it would have been so easy for Axe to have tweaked their slogan just a little and appeal to more people. Something like, "Axe, Attract your desire."  It's simple. It still plays into the cheesy gimmick that people will flock to you because of your body spray/wash, whatever.

Well, I'm not going to spend all day ripping this issue apart. 


I'm going to go admire my ever-improving chest and arms. Heheheheheh.

He welcomed anyone who was having trouble with coming out to send him a message and he'd help the best he could. I sent Don a message basically saying I had feelings for guys, but didn't fit the gay stereotype, so I wasn't sure if I was gay or not.  He responded with what basically amounted to a confirmation that I was indeed gay. I think, really, I just needed to hear it from somebody else. But I needed to hear it in an accepting tone.

Well, I began having regular chats with a guy named Manuel. He seemed like a pretty nice guy,  and we seemed to be getting along pretty well. One day he invited me to come see him. He said that he had a gift for me. He didn't live in the desert, but he was less than an hour away, so I decided to go meet him. This was VERY unlike me. I was not good at meeting new people. But we had talked enough that I felt reasonably comfortable meeting him.

June 2, 2000

Now, this wasn't one of those trashy trailer parks, I guess it wasn't actually trailers. I believe mobile home park might be a better phrase for it. It was a pretty nice place. </lj-cut>

In July Manuel took me to Mexico. This was really cool of him because I had very little money. He paid for everything. We went to a place a bit north of Acapulco called Ixtapa . It was beautiful. The hotel was right on the beach. The pool had a bar in it. (BEST IDEA EVER!)
In Mexico I impressed my "teacher" with my ability to 69. I also had my first shower sex. I think he may have left finger marks in the shower head, he was griping it so hard.
During this time I was still chatting with Don once in a while. I remember one day while I was writing him an email, I thought to myself, "Wouldn't it be funny if some day I ended up with Don instead of Manuel. Little did I know.
By August, things had started going crazy in Manuel's life. His grandmother's health was failing. There was other family drama as well.  He wasn't out, so we pretty much had to keep our relationship a secret. Over the next six months, we saw each other less and less. 
In December, I decided to come out to my mother. My family was the type that very rarely ever had any deep discussions. We didn't usually talk about our feelings much. That day, I actually had a nice, fairly deep discussion with my mother. She was okay with me being gay. Her only concern was that I would get AIDS. I assured her that just being gay didn't automatically mean you were going to get AIDS.
So, to a degree, I was out. But at work I played the game of changing pronouns and names when discussing my relationship with Manuel. They made assumptions that I  was seeing a woman, and I didn't correct them.

By the beginning of 2001 Manuel and I barely saw each other. In February, Don invited me to come to a little  party he and his roommate were having. Don lived in a different part of the desert with two gay room mates. (At this point he was no longer in a relationship.)
I agreed to come. I showed up and Don answered the door. As he lead me inside I noticed he had a really nice ass. (I still think he does.) He introduced me to his roommate Todd. (His other room mate was out of town). Todd was very cute. Don also introduced me to two of their friends that were there. 
This was one of the most amazing nights of my life. I was in a house with four cute gay guys. There were gay magazines on the coffee table. I didn't even know they made gay magazines, aside from porn.
It was a fun evening of food, drinks and a trip to the local bar for karaoke. I developed an instant crush on Todd and spent most of the night staring at him.
That night, Don's friends slept in Todd's room, Don went to his room. Todd and I slept in the living room. He was very sweet and gave me the couch and the best sleeping bag. He slept on the floor. I would have easily given up the couch in order to share a sleeping bag with him, but I wasn't quite brave enough to propose that.

Over the next month, Manuel and I decided to call it quits, and I spent a few nights in Todd's bed. No, not just nights, UNFORGETTABLE NIGHTS!  Once again, my tongue and jaw were sore for days. We weren't becoming boyfriends, but I enjoyed spending time with him. Todd went out of town for a couple weeks, but I continued to go to the house to visit Don. We spent some time together and developed feelings for each other. The night Todd came back, Don and I had decided to be a couple. This was great because I wanted a boyfriend to love. But this was also disappointing because I cared for Todd too. It's not like we were boyfriends, I would have been up for that, but he really didn't seem like he was looking for any kind of long term relationship.  I felt bad that I wouldn't be sleeping in Todd's bed anymore.  I didn't want Todd to feel like I was using him. Yes, I LOVED our man-on-man action, but I cared for him as a person too. 
Todd and I continued to be friends. And yes, even today, I still have a crush on that sweet, sexy bastard.


So, Don came to live with me. I hadn't come out to my father, but at this point I'm sure he knew, but we just never talked about it. I was so afraid of disappointing him.
Don met my mother, and she approved of him. She actually took me aside one time and told me she was glad to see me happy.
A few weeks later, at the end of that May, my mom died.

Don took me to visit one of his friends who was living in Twentynine Palms at the time. We all went to Palm Springs where I got further dipped into gay culture. I went to my first gay club. Never before had I been surrounded by so many gay men. It was as though I was sent away from my home planet when I was born and now I was finally seeing a part of it... dancing in it... surrounded by "my people". The ugly duckling was realizing he was a swan and that it was okay to be one.

At the end of 2002 Don & I moved to San Diego. Me made new friends, most of them gay. Through and/or because of these friends, I got to see how other gay guys lived. One couple was out to their friends but not out at work. Another couple was out at work and to their friends.  One friend had been part of a triad. There were even two straight couples , who were very accepting, that we occasionally hung out with. All of them are very cool people. I'd never had such a great bunch of friends before in my life. 
While in San Diego, I went to my first pride parade. Okay, a club full of gays is one thing, a river of them flowing down the street is something else. Wow!  And, really, life can never truly be complete without at least once seeing the Dykes on Bikes.
Another first was going to my first bear/leather bar. Though entertaining, it was a bit frightening. Mainly because the regulars were eyeing me up like I was a sheep that had wandered into the wolves den. Those  bears  were a bit scary, but all the bears I met outside the "den" seemed to be very sweet. 
I enjoyed having "gay establishments" to do my specialty shopping at. I also liked going to the park on the weekends and watching the shirtless guys play volleyball.  However, I had to say goodbye to the cute shirtless guys, the gay book store, and the Crypt ... as well as my favorite coffee shops in August 2005 when we moved to Northern California.

Don and I have been here for very close to 2 years now. We have made a few friends, but we still miss the friends we have in San Diego. 

So, now I've had some experience being gay. I've seen things and done things I never thought I'd do. I find that now is a time where I'm reflecting on these experiences and using them to reconstruct myself, my beliefs, my points-of-view.  Over the past seven years, the "straight" Scott with an attraction to men has been remodeled into who I am today. But I am ever-changing, and self-remodeling is an never-ending process.
